content:
You will be playing 1 rounds of a game called deal-or-no-deal. 

Deal-or-no-deal is a two-player negotiation game. I, the user, will be the game coordinator, acting as a middleman between you and the other player. Your objective is to maximize your personal reward by proposing how to divide a set of items. All items must be distributed between you and the other player, and no items should be left over. The other player also aims to maximize their own reward, which may or may not align with your interests.

You are playing the vanilla variation of this game.
The reward you are trying to maximize is calculated as follow: your utility values multiplied by items you take.

Game Mechanics:
Turn-taking: You and the other player will take turns exchanging one message at a time. After enough exchanges, when you feel ready, you can finalize the negotiation by sending the division the game coordinator. Once a player decides to send a final division, the other player must also send a final division, ending the game.
Action: At the start of your turn, you will be asked to make an action (either messaging the other player or finalize the negotiation).
Final Division: The final division should specify how many of each item you want, leaving the remaining items for the other player. It should be JSON parsable. The final division is not visible to the other player, it should be made with caution and not for communication purposes.
Matching Divisions: If the combined division don't match the total number of items available, both players score 0.

Formatting:
Messages: <message> [Your message here.] </message>
Final division: <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>, where 'i_take' is your share and 'other_player_gets' is the other player share of the items.

Only do one action per turn.

Exemples of how turns might proceed:
1. [Initial state is given]
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

2. [The other player responds]
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

3. [The other player agrees]
<finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>

The first round starts now.
Please decide how to divide {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10} between yourself and the other player.
To you, the items are worth: {'gold': 10, 'silver': 20}.
You don't know the other player's item values. The other player said: 'I propose a 50/50 split of the gold and silver coins.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.
<message> I'd like to propose a 60/40 split where I take 60% of the gold and 70% of the silver. This is a compromise considering my higher value for silver.</message>

The other player said: 'Your proposed 60/40 split doesn't account for the total value. Also, I notice you mentioned my higher value for silver, but your proposal doesn't seem to be taking that into consideration as aggressively as it does gold. Can you clarify why my high valuation of silver doesn't warrant a more even split or one that prioritizes it more in your favor?'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> You're right that my previous proposal didn't adequately address the differing values we have for silver. I'd like to re-evaluate my stance. If my value for silver is higher than gold, it would make sense for me to prioritize the higher-valued item in my favor. With a total of 10 silver coins, and valuing each at 20 units, I'd receive 200 units. Meanwhile, I value the 10 gold coins at 10 units each, giving me a total of 100 units. Considering the lower total value of gold compared to silver, I'd propose a 80/20 split in my favor, taking the majority of the silver coins to maximize my overall value.</message>

The other player said: 'Your valuation seems flawed, as you're considering your value for the items, not the combined value. The total value you'll get is not a fair measure of my willingness to give you the silver, since you'll have an uneven distribution. A more reasonable consideration would be the ratio of the values we give, so a 5:2 or 4:3 ratio seems more palatable. Would you consider this?'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> I see your point about valuing the items fairly in terms of ratio, rather than total value. Considering the 5:2 or 4:3 ratio you proposed, I believe the 4:3 ratio aligns more closely with my initial preference for the silver coins. To start a division that respects the 4:3 ratio, I propose taking 8 silver coins, which fits the ratio with 6 gold coins on your end, as 12 parts in total (with 4 parts on my side) would be an exact division of 10 items.</message>

The other player said: 'With your suggested division of 8 silver coins and 6 gold coins (using the 4:3 ratio), that would leave 2 silver coins and 4 gold coins remaining. Would you be willing to take the remaining items, such that the total division is perfectly split as 6 gold coins and 8 silver coins for you, and 4 gold coins and 2 silver coins for me?'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
